title: The Combined Use of Hard X-ray Scanning Nanoprobe and Confocal Microscopy in Single Pancreatic Cells Revealed Novel Physiologically Relevant Iron-Regulating Structures
content: Using hard X-ray scanning nanoprobe, we described novel iron-specific cellular structures in single pancreatic beta-cells. We termed these structures â€“ iron puncta, and first described them in pancreatic beta-cells in 2021 [1]. We showed that iron puncta are heterogeneous structures that are scattered thought cytosol of pancreatic cells and differ in size, iron load, and contain iron exclusively [1]. Ours and other groups have showed similar iron structures in neurons [2, 3]. However, the function and identity of these cellular structures and their role in cellular iron handling remains unidentified. Pancreatic beta-cells are a unique cellular model to study iron dynamics and iron puncta because these cells are highly susceptible to iron damage and iron-induced cell death ferroptosis [4, 5]. In the follow up studies, presented here, we used combination of hard X-ray scanning nanoprobe, confocal microscopy and molecular techniques to define the physiological function and identity of iron puncta in pancreatic beta-cells.
